text:
DTBF was then applied as additive in the OSC devices based 
on PBDB-T:IO-4Cl and PBDB-T:IT-4Cl. As plotted in Figure 5c 
and summarized in Table S5, Supporting Information, after 
being treated with DTBF, the PCE of the IT-4Cl-based devices was 
dramatically enhanced from 6.54% to 8.40%, while the photo
voltaic performances showed slight changes for the IO-4Cl-based 
devices. Meanwhile, we applied DTBF to other OSC devices 
based on different active layers, including P3HT:ZY-4Cl, PBDB
T:IO-4F, PBDB-TF: BTP-eC9, and PBDB-TF: IT-4F, which were 
classified into two groups according to the quadrupole moment 
of their acceptor end-groups (Figure S9, Supporting Informa
tion). The optimal DTBF concentration was calculated for each 
case when the mole ratio of the acceptor and DTBF was 1:2 
and all the devices were prepared with thermal annealing treat
ment. The obtained PCE were summarized in Figure 5d. Com
pared with the IO-4F- and ZY4Cl-based devices, the application 
of DTBF significantly enhanced the PCE of the IT-4F- and BTP
eC9-based OSCs. These two groups of OSCs showed a similar 
phenomenon with the comparison between IO-4Cl and IT-4Cl. 
The DTBF-processed device based on PBDB-TF:BTP-eC9 dem
onstrated a high PCE of 17.5% (Figure S10, Supporting Informa
tion). Based on the theoretical, morphological, and photovoltaic 
results mentioned above, it can be speculated that the strong 
charge quadrupole interaction between the acceptor and addi
tive is critical for the obtained compact and ordered molecular 
packing and thus improves photovoltaic performance in OSCs.

DTBF was then applied as additive in the OSC devices based 
on PBDB-T:IO-4Cl and PBDB-T:IT-4Cl. As plotted in Figure 5c 
and summarized in Table S5, Supporting Information, after 
being treated with DTBF, the PCE of the IT-4Cl-based devices was 
dramatically enhanced from 6.54% to 8.40%, while the photo
voltaic performances showed slight changes for the IO-4Cl-based 
devices. Meanwhile, we applied DTBF to other OSC devices 
based on different active layers, including P3HT:ZY-4Cl, PBDB
T:IO-4F, PBDB-TF: BTP-eC9, and PBDB-TF: IT-4F, which were 
classified into two groups according to the quadrupole moment 
of their acceptor end-groups (Figure S9, Supporting Informa
tion). The optimal DTBF concentration was calculated for each 
case when the mole ratio of the acceptor and DTBF was 1:2 
and all the devices were prepared with thermal annealing treat
ment. The obtained PCE were summarized in Figure 5d. Com
pared with the IO-4F- and ZY4Cl-based devices, the application 
of DTBF significantly enhanced the PCE of the IT-4F- and BTP
eC9-based OSCs. These two groups of OSCs showed a similar 
phenomenon with the comparison between IO-4Cl and IT-4Cl. 
The DTBF-processed device based on PBDB-TF:BTP-eC9 dem
onstrated a high PCE of 17.5% (Figure S10, Supporting Informa
tion). Based on the theoretical, morphological, and photovoltaic 
results mentioned above, it can be speculated that the strong 
charge quadrupole interaction between the acceptor and addi
tive is critical for the obtained compact and ordered molecular 
packing and thus improves photovoltaic performance in OSCs.

To examine the effect of CN and DTT dual additives treat 
ment on optimizing the morphology, OSCs were fabricated 
using conventional device architecture of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/
 active layer/PDINO[26]/Al (Figure 1a). Detailed experimental 
procedures are described in Supporting Information. The con
trol PM6:Y6-based devices processed with conventional treat
ment of 0.5% (v/v) CN and TA at 110 °C for 10 min yielded a 
maximum PCE of 15.74%, with an open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 0.822 V, a short-circuit current density (Jsc) of 25.91 mA cm−2, 
and FF of 73.9% (Figure 2a and Table 1). In comparison with the 
control devices without any treatment (PCE = 15.37%), applying 
different weight ratio of DTT as additive for the PM6:Y6 blend 
f
 ilm effectively enabled better device performance, and a  
maximum PCE of 16.03% was achieved when the active layer 
was processed by 50% DTT (Table S1, Supporting Information). 
By incorporating 10% DTT (weight ratio relative to Y6) along 
with 0.5% CN as dual additives in chloroform, followed by TA 
at 90 °C for 10 min for the PM6:Y6 blend, an improved FF of 
75.4% associated with a slightly higher Jsc of 26.16 mA cm−2 was 
obtained, delivering a higher PCE of 16.50% as compared to 
the control device processed with the conventional CN additive 
(Table S2, Supporting Information). When increasing the DTT 
content to 20%, the PCE of the device was further enhanced  
to 16.74%, with a Jsc of 26.20 mA cm−2 and a FF of 76.0%  
(Table S2, Supporting Information). Optimal device perfor
mance was obtained when 25% DTT and 0.5% CN was used, 
giving a maximum PCE of 16.97%, with a Voc of 0.839 V, a Jsc 
of 26.42 mA cm−2, and a FF of 76.5%. Afterward, the higher content of 30% and 40% DTT led to a lower PCE of 16.89% 
and 16.28%, respectively. It should be noted that all the devices 
yielded over 16% PCEs by using dual additives of CN and DTT 
treatment with the weight ratio of DTT ranged from 10% to 
40%, which are higher than that of the control device using 
only CN as additive.

(Table S2, Supporting Information). Optimal device perfor

of 26.42 mA cm−2, and a FF of 76.5%. Afterward, the higher content of 30% and 40% DTT led to a lower PCE of 16.89%

To examine the effect of CN and DTT dual additives treat 
ment on optimizing the morphology, OSCs were fabricated 
using conventional device architecture of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/
 active layer/PDINO[26]/Al (Figure 1a). Detailed experimental 
procedures are described in Supporting Information. The con
trol PM6:Y6-based devices processed with conventional treat
ment of 0.5% (v/v) CN and TA at 110 °C for 10 min yielded a 
maximum PCE of 15.74%, with an open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 0.822 V, a short-circuit current density (Jsc) of 25.91 mA cm−2, 
and FF of 73.9% (Figure 2a and Table 1). In comparison with the 
control devices without any treatment (PCE = 15.37%), applying 
different weight ratio of DTT as additive for the PM6:Y6 blend 
f
 ilm effectively enabled better device performance, and a  
maximum PCE of 16.03% was achieved when the active layer 
was processed by 50% DTT (Table S1, Supporting Information). 
By incorporating 10% DTT (weight ratio relative to Y6) along 
with 0.5% CN as dual additives in chloroform, followed by TA 
at 90 °C for 10 min for the PM6:Y6 blend, an improved FF of 
75.4% associated with a slightly higher Jsc of 26.16 mA cm−2 was 
obtained, delivering a higher PCE of 16.50% as compared to 
the control device processed with the conventional CN additive 
(Table S2, Supporting Information). When increasing the DTT 
content to 20%, the PCE of the device was further enhanced  
to 16.74%, with a Jsc of 26.20 mA cm−2 and a FF of 76.0%  
(Table S2, Supporting Information). Optimal device perfor
mance was obtained when 25% DTT and 0.5% CN was used, 
giving a maximum PCE of 16.97%, with a Voc of 0.839 V, a Jsc 
of 26.42 mA cm−2, and a FF of 76.5%. Afterward, the higher content of 30% and 40% DTT led to a lower PCE of 16.89% 
and 16.28%, respectively. It should be noted that all the devices 
yielded over 16% PCEs by using dual additives of CN and DTT 
treatment with the weight ratio of DTT ranged from 10% to 
45%, which are higher than that of the control device using 
only CN as additive.

Due to the strong self-assembly of nonfullerene acceptor Y6, 
realizing high performance in the Y6-based OSCs heavily relies 
on the selection of processing solvent with low boiling point 
(e.g., chloroform), which can prevent the over aggregation of Y6 
during the film formation. Otherwise, using high boiling point 
solvent (e.g., chlorobenzene and o-xylene) to build the devices 
generally results in poor photovoltaic performance because of 
the excessive self-assembly aggregation of Y6.[18,27] The conven
tional solvent additive treatments show limited effect on regu
lating the morphology of Y6-based blend casting from high 
boiling point solvents. We then examine the advantage of the 
CN and DTT dual additives treatment for the OSCs processed 
by the high boiling point solvents. Relative to the lower PCE of 
13.23% obtained in the control PM6:Y6-based device processed 
by chlorobenzene with CN additive, a much higher PCE of 
15.85% was achieved by applying the dual additives of CN and 
DTT to treat the blend, along with significantly improved FF 
of 77.0% (Table 1 and Figure 2a). Particularly, such dual addi
tives treatment showed encouraging effect on regulating the 
morphology of the nonhalogen-solvent o-xylene-processed 
PM6:Y6 blend, recording an impressive PCE of 16.16% and a 
FF of 76.2% (Table 1 and Figure 2b). Contrastively, the control 
device treated with CN additive showed a much poorer PCE of 
12.11% and a lower FF of 67.8%. The significant improvement 
of device performance enabled by the dual additives treatment 
of CN and DTT was also established in the nonhalogen-solvent 
toluene-processed PM6:Y6 blend (as shown in Table 1), further 
demonstrating the advantages of the duel additives treatment 
in the morphology control.

It is noteworthy that the synergistic effect of CN and DTT 
dual additives treatment effectively led to significantly improved 
FF values and increased PCEs of the OSCs (Figure 6c,d).  
Particularly, FF values exceeding 80% should be a rarity in the 
reported OSCs.[35,36] According to the evaluation of the exciton 
charge dissociation and charge recombination properties  
in these devices (as shown in Figures S7 and S8, Supporting 
Information), the dual additives treatment of CN and DTT 
favors to improve their charge extraction efficiency and 
suppress the charge recombination as compared to the conventional CN additive treatment, which are consistent 
with the results observed in the PM6:Y6 system. Similar to 
the PM6:Y6 blend, the PTQ10:DTT showed obviously higher 
χ parameter of 1.087 than that of 0.017 for the Y6:DTT blend 
and 0.432 for the m-BTP-PhC6:DTT blend (as shown in Figure 
S5, Supporting Information), indicating the higher miscibility 
of DTT with nonfullerene acceptor (Y6/m-BTP-PhC6) com
pared to the polymer donor PTQ10. Relative to the PTQ10:Y6 
and PTQ10:m-BTP-PhC6 blend films treated with CN additive 
alone, better nanoscale phase separation with more favorable  aggregation was realized in the films processed with the dual 
additives of CN and DTT (as shown in Figures S9 and S10, 
Supporting Information), suggesting that the additional DTT 
additive effectively restricted the over self-assembling of the Y6 
and m-BTP-PhC6 acceptors in the active layers. Relative to the 
CN additive treatment for the PTQ10:Y6 blend, the dual addi
tives treatment of CN and DTT also enhanced the preferential 
face-on orientation and narrowed the π–π interaction distance 
along the OOP direction (as shown in Figure S11, Supporting 
Information), which agrees with the phenomenon observed 
in the PM6:Y6 system mentioned above. Apparently, the work 
mechanism of the DTT additive treatment in the PTQ10
based systems is the same as that established in the PM6:Y6 
blend, demonstrating the generality of this morphology con
trolling effect of the dual additives treatment. Other than the 
Y6-series-based systems, this morphology control approach 
also showed positive effect on optimizing the morphology of 
PM6:IT-4F blend film. Compared with the control device pro
cessed by conventional CN additive (PCE = 12.65%), a higher 
PCE of 13.87% was achieved in the device treated by the dual 
additives of 1% CN and 40% DTT (Table S10, Supporting  
Information).

It is noteworthy that the synergistic effect of CN and DTT 
dual additives treatment effectively led to significantly improved 
FF values and increased PCEs of the OSCs (Figure 6c,d).

Supporting Information), suggesting that the additional DTT

Information).
